Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Foundations of Energy Efficient Wireless Multimedia Broadcasting

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Wireless multimedia broadcast has been the central of human entertainments for a century. While the broadcasting signaling is being transformed to digital, its infrastructure is still incapable of supporting the full potential of wireless digital broadcast. This project develops a comprehensive framework to enable scalable and adaptive wireless multimedia broadcasting for an envisioned cellular-type infrastructure, as well as for infrastructures in transitional stages. The project consists of three components: 1) an adaptive channel coding scheme, 2) a stochastic power control and antenna beamforming algorithm, and 3) a feedback channel medium access control protocol. In the first step, the research develops an adaptive coding scheme to enable efficient and scalable broadcast communication over dynamic wireless channels with minimum channel information at the transmitters. In the second step, the research develops a stochastic power control and antenna beamforming framework to optimize energy efficiency of the broadcast system under communication throughput and delay constraints. In the third step, the research develops a medium access control protocol to feedback necessary channel information without sacrificing system scalability using a minimum amount of feedback channel bandwidth. This project also develops a demonstration system in wireless computer networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For almost a century, wireless TV and radio broadcasts have relied on analog communication technologies. Although systematic transformation to digital signaling started recently, the current infrastructure, inherited from analog systems, still does not have the capability to exploit the full potential of digital broadcasting. We envisioned a cellular-type infrastructure that has the potential of providing relatively flat signal to noise ratio (SNR) coverage with low transmission power to all users in the area. Its implementation, however, requires channel coding to have the capability of combining signals from multiple transmission stations and also requires the feedback channel to have the capability of handling bursty feedback packets efficiently.

To overcome the first challenge, we developed a fountain channel coding theory for multimedia broadcasting over discrete memoryless channels with arbitrary unknown erasures. Our results demonstrated that communication error probability of the fountain broadcast system can be made to decrease exponentially in the number of received symbols for any fountain rate below the capacity. A near optimal error exponent can be achieved with a coding complexity growing only linearly in the number of received symbols. The proposed fountain coding approach supports efficient combination of signals from multiple transmitters. It also possesses several other interesting properties, such as rate compatibility, that are important to broadcasting applications.

To overcome the second challenge, we investigated the problem of channel coding in distributed and random access communication systems. In a random multiple access system, we assume that each transmitter is equipped with multiple codes. In each time slot, a transmitter can arbitrarily choose a code to encode its message without sharing such a decision with any other transmitter or with the receiver. We showed that even though reliable message decoding cannot be guaranteed in this case, the notion of fundamental performance limitation still exists. By requiring either reliable decoding or reliable collision report at the receiver while maximizing the support of reliable decoding, we defined and characterized the achievable region of the system and showed that it coincides with the classical Shannon information region. The result was then extended to a wide range of distributed communication systems with practical settings such as single user decoding, finite codeword length, compound channel, etc. Our new channel coding theory enabled a key enhancement to the physical-link layer interface in the current network architecture, in the sense that a data link layer user can now be equipped with multiple transmission options. We further investigated the distributed medium access control problems brought by such an interface enhancement. Early results demonstrated that the interface enhancement has the potential of significantly improving the efficiency of distributed wireless networks.

The research works supported by this project is in line with our long term effort of bridging information theory with network theory. The gap between the two traditional theories is viewed by us as a key bottleneck for the further advance of wireless networks. The particular research progress in fountain communication will help the development of scalable multicast applications. The progress on channel coding for distributed communication will help improving our fundamental understandings as well as practical operations of distributed communication networks. The research progresses have been fully integrated into the relevant graduate and undergraduate curriculum and this will help broadening the knowledge and the vision of our graduate and undergraduate students.
